questions.text: Which among the following carries a slightly increased risk of invasive breast carcinoma based on the pathological examination of benign breast tissue?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Papilloma carries a slightly increased risk of invasive breast cancer.

choices.text: First child at a later age

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a protective factor against breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Protective factors for breast cancer include:

  • Breast feeding
  • First pregnancy at an early age (Option B ruled out )
  • Late menarche (Option D ruled out )
  • Early menopause
  • Multiparity (Option A ruled out )

Breast cancer is the most common cause of death in middle-aged women in Western countries.

questions.text: Which of the following is a modifiable risk factor for breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Age at first live birth is a modifiable risk factor for breast carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following genes is most commonly associated with the development of breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1) is a tumour suppressor gene located on chromosome 17.

  • Mutations in BRCA1 significantly increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancers.
  • BRCA1-related breast cancers are often:
    • Triple-negative(ER-, PR-, HER2-)
    • High-grade invasive ductal carcinomas
    • Early onset (<50 years)
  • Lifetime risk of breast cancer:~55-65% for BRCA1 mutation carriers.

Investigations & Management:

  • Genetic testing:BRCA1/2 mutation analysis for high-risk individuals (family history, early-onset breast/ovarian cancer).
  • Screening:Enhanced surveillance with MRI/mammography starting earlier.
  • Preventive options:
    • Prophylactic mastectomy or oophorectomy in mutation carriers.
    • Lifestyle modifications and chemoprevention (tamoxifen/raloxifene).

Explanation for other options:

BRCA 2 (Option B): Also a tumour suppressor gene on chromosome 13. Increases breast and ovarian cancer risk, but is slightly less commonly associated with triple-negative tumours than BRCA1. Lifetime risk of breast cancer: ~45-55%.

PTEN (Option C): Tumour suppressor gene; mutations are associated with Cowden syndrome, which increases breast cancer risk among other tumours. Less common cause of hereditary breast cancer compared to BRCA1/2.

KRAS (Option D): Oncogene commonly involved in colon, lung, and pancreatic cancers.
Rarely implicated in breast cancer.

Key takeaway:

p53 Mutation and Breast Cancer

  • Gene:TP53, located on chromosome 17p13.1, encodes the p53 tumour suppressor protein, often called the "guardian of the genome."
  • Function:p53 regulates cell cycle arrest, DNA repair, senescence, and apoptosis in response to DNA damage, preventing propagation of mutated cells.
  • Mutation Impact:
    • Loss-of-function or missense mutations in p53 lead to uncontrolled cell proliferationand accumulation of genetic errors.
    • p53 mutations are associated with high-grade, aggressive breast cancers, often with poor prognosis.
  • Clinical Association:
    • Found in Li-Fraumeni syndrome, a rare hereditary disorder causing early-onset breast cancer and multiple other malignancies.
    • Sporadic p53 mutations occur in 20-40% of breast cancers, particularly triple-negative breast cancers.

questions.text: Which subtype of breast carcinoma is not known to occur with the BRCA1 mutation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PR positive type is not known to occur with the BRCA 1 mutation.

  • BRCA1-associated tumors are typically:
    • High grade
    • Hormone receptor-negative (ER- and PR-negative)(Option B Ruled out )
    • HER2-negative (Option D Ruled out )
    • Triple negative phenotype (Option A Ruled out )
    • Aneuploid, with increased S-phase fraction
  • These features make them biologically more aggressive and with a less favourable histopathology compared with BRCA2-associated cancers.
  • BRCA2-associated tumours, in contrast, are more often hormone receptor-positive (ER/PR positive).

questions.text: Which histological finding is linked to the lowest relative risk of breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Proliferative Disease without Atypia includes lesions like usual ductal hyperplasia, sclerosing adenosis, and papillomas without atypia.

  • These are benign proliferative changesin the breast epithelium.
  • Relative risk (RR) for breast cancer:~1.5-2× higher than the general population, lowest among the listed options.
  • Often discovered incidentally on biopsy for other lesions.

Investigations & Management:

  • Proliferative disease without atypia:Usually no surgical intervention, routine follow-up and mammography.
  • Atypical lesions & LCIS:Consider excision, chemoprevention (e.g., tamoxifen), and close surveillance.

Explanation for other options:

Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia (Option B): Pre-malignant lesion with abnormal proliferation of ductal epithelial cells with cytologic atypia. RR for breast cancer: ~4-5× higher. Considered a marker for increased risk and is sometimes managed with surgical excision.

Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia (Option C): Proliferation of lobular epithelial cells with atypia. RR: ~4-5× higher. Associated with bilateral risk; often detected incidentally.

Lobular Carcinoma in Situ (LCIS) (Option D): Considered both a risk marker and a non-invasive neoplasm. RR: ~8-10× higher than the general population. Increases risk in both breasts, requiring close surveillance or chemoprevention in some cases.

Key takeaway:

choices.text: Presents with painful, swollen breasts with cutaneous oedema
It results from the blockage of intramuscular lymphatics with carcinoma cells

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding inflammatory breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inflammatory carcinoma is due to the blockage of the subdermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells.

  • Rare
  • Highly aggressive (Option A ruled out )
  • Presents as a painful, swollen breast, which is warm with cutaneous oedema. (Option B ruled out )
  • Due to the blockage of the subdermal lymphatics by carcinoma cells.
  • Inflammatory cancer usually involves at least one-third of the breast and may mimic a breast abscess. (Option D ruled out )
  • A biopsy will confirm the diagnosis and show undifferentiated carcinoma cells.
  • It used to be rapidly fatal, but with aggressive chemotherapy and radiotherapy and with salvage surgery, the prognosis has improved considerably.

questions.text: Where does the lymphatic spread occur for a tumour in the posterior one-third of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lymphatic drainage of the breast is not uniform and depends on the site of the tumour.

  • Anterior 2/3 (superficial and central breast tissue):Mainly drains to the axillary lymph nodes (Level I → II → III, depending on extent).
  • Posterior 1/3 (deep portion, particularly the medial quadrants and retroareolar region):Drains predominantly to the internal mammary lymph nodes via perforating branches that accompany the internal thoracic vessels.

This pattern is clinically important because tumours in the inner quadrants/posterior third are more likely to metastasise to the internal mammary chain, which is not palpable on clinical exam but detectable on imaging.
Involvement of the supraclavicular nodes and of any contralateral lymph nodes represents advanced disease.

questions.text: Breast cancer most commonly metastasises to which part of the skeletal system?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Skeletal metastases occur via the bloodstream in breast carcinoma. The commonly involved sites, in order of frequency, include:

  • Lumbar vertebrae - most common
  • Femur (Option B ruled out )
  • Thoracic vertebrae
  • Ribs (Option D ruled out )
  • Skull (Option C ruled out )

The deposits are generally more osteolytic than osteoblastic.

Metastases may also commonly occur in the liver, lungs and brain and, occasionally, the adrenal glands and ovaries via the bloodstream.

Hematogenous Spread of Breast Carcinoma via Batson's Plexus

  • Batson's plexus (vertebral venous plexus)is a network of valveless veins running along the entire vertebral column, connecting the deep pelvic veins and thoracic veins to the internal vertebral venous plexuses.
  • Because these veins are valveless, blood flow can be bidirectional and influenced by changes in intra-abdominal or intrathoracic pressure (e.g., coughing, straining).
  • This unique feature allows cancer cells from the breast(and also from pelvic organs like the prostate) to spread directly to the vertebrae and spinal structures without first passing through the lungs.
  • Hence, breast carcinoma commonly metastasises to the vertebral columnvia Batson's plexus, leading to bony metastases and sometimes spinal cord compression.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the findings in the given image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Peau d'orange (skin of the orange) is seen in breast carcinoma when there is infiltration of the dermal lymphatics by malignant cells.

Explanation of other Options:

Skin tethering(Option B): Skin tethering is a clinical sign seen in breast carcinoma, where the skin over the tumour appears pulled in, puckered, or dimpled. It is a visible and/or palpable abnormality that may indicate the infiltration of Cooper's ligaments (suspensory ligaments of the breast) by a malignant tumour.

Eczema of breast(Option C): Eczema of the breast" refers to inflammatory skin changes affecting the nipple and/or areola, which can be benign (eczema/dermatitis) or a sign of underlying malignancy such as Paget's disease of the breast.

Skin puckering(Option D): Skin puckering is a clinical sign often seen in breast carcinoma, particularly invasive types. It appears as dimpling or wrinkling of the skin overlying the tumour and is an important indicator of potential malignancy.

questions.text: What is the TNM stage of breast carcinoma in a patient with a 3 cm breast tumour, metastasis to 2 axillary lymph nodes, and no distant metastasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TNM stage of breast carcinoma in a patient with a 3 cm breast tumour, metastasis to 2 axillary lymph nodes, and no distant metastasis is T2N1aM0

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic method for phyllodes tumours of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Excisional biopsy followed by careful pathologic review is the best method of diagnosing phyllodes tumours.

  • Phyllodes tumours are seen on mammography as round densities with smooth borders and are indistinguishable from fibroadenomas.
  • Ultrasonography may reveal a discrete structure with cystic spaces
  • Cytologicalanalysis is unreliable in differentiating a low-grade phyllodes tumour from a fibroadenoma.

questions.text: Which condition refers to angiosarcoma developing in the ipsilateral arm as a complication of chronic post-surgical lymphedema?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to the development of lymphangiosarcoma (angiosarcoma) in the ipsilateral upper limb following long-standing chronic lymphedema.
  • It is most often seen after radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy in breast cancer patients.
  • The tumour usually appears as multiple purplish nodules or plaques on the edematous arm.
  • Prognosis is generally poor, as angiosarcoma is aggressive and metastasises early.

Explanation of other options:

Dubin-Johnson syndrome (Option A): A rare inherited benign disorder of bilirubin metabolism. Characterised by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and a black liver on gross pathology. Not related to lymphedema or angiosarcoma.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome (Option C): A complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Involves perihepatic adhesions ("violin-string adhesions") between the liver capsule and abdominal wall.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (Option D): A group of inherited connective tissue disorders.
Presents with hyperextensible skin, hypermobile joints, and fragile tissues. No link with post-mastectomy lymphedema or angiosarcoma.

questions.text: What is the stage of the disease for T2N2M0 for breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The stage of the disease for T2N2M0 for breast carcinoma is Stage IIIA.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not considered an absolute contraindication for radiation treatment in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the options given are relative contraindications of radiotherapy in breast cancer.

Pregnancy is an absolute contraindication.

Contraindications to Radiation Therapy

choices.text: Dermal lymph node invasion is common
Erythema is confined to the lesion

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of inflammatory breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In inflammatory breast cancer (IBC), erythema is not confined to a localised lesion but rather involves at least one-third of the breast, giving it a diffuse, inflamed appearance (peau d'orange).

Key Features of Inflammatory Breast Cancer:

  • Rapid onset of breast erythema, swelling, and warmth.
  • Peau d'orange appearance due to dermal lymphatic invasion.
  • Distant metastasis is common (option A ruled out ).
  • Dermal lymphatic invasion is common(option B ruled out).
  • The cancer is not sharply delineated and often infiltrative (option D ruled out).
  • Poor prognosis; aggressive course.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a technique of breast conservation surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patey's procedure is a type of mastectomy. It is not a breast-conserving surgery.

  • Breast-conserving surgeries include lumpectomy,partial mastectomy, segmental mastectomy, segmentectomy, tylectomy, and wide local excision. (Options A, B & D ruled out)
  • Breast-conserving surgery removes the malignancy with a surrounding rim of grossly normal breast parenchyma.

choices.text: Shouldn't be advised for reconstruction surgery

questions.text: What should be the ideal time for reconstruction surgery for breast carcinoma after radiation therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reconstruction surgery for breast carcinoma after radiation therapy is generally not recommended for 1 to 2 years to facilitate healing and recovery.

In irradiated tissue, there is a higher rate of tissue necrosis, seroma formation, and infection.

The use of vascularized tissue from outside the radiation field is the favoured approach. If the main deformity is caused by asymmetry with the contralateral breast, a mastopexy of the contralateral breast can be considered.

questions.text: Which among the following structures is preserved in the patient's mastectomy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Patey's mastectomy, the breast and associated structures are dissected en bloc, and the excised mass is composed of the following:

  • Whole breast tissue (Option A ruled out )
  • Skin over the breast tissue(Option B ruled out )
  • Nipple areola complex
  • Fat, fascia and lymph nodes of the axilla. (Option D ruled out )

The pectoralis minor muscle is either divided or retracted to gain access to the upper two-thirds of the axilla.

The axillary vein and nerves to the serratus anterior and latissimus dorsi should be preserved.

choices.text: Pathological status of the axillary lymph nodes

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in patients with breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence and number of metastatic axillary lymph nodes are the single most important prognostic factor in breast cancer.
  • It strongly predicts overall survival, risk of recurrence, and guides the need for adjuvant therapy.
  • Patients with node-negative disease generally have a much better prognosis than those with node-positive disease.

Explanation for Other Options:

Size of the tumour (option A): Tumour size is an important prognostic factor, as larger tumours (>5 cm) have a higher risk of recurrence and metastasis. However, its prognostic significance is less than lymph node involvement.

Age of the patient (option C): Younger (<35 years) or older (>70 years) age may influence prognosis slightly due to tumour biology and comorbidities. Age alone is not as strong a predictor as nodal status.

Distant metastasis (option D): Presence of distant metastasis (Stage IV) indicates poor prognosis, but this reflects advanced disease rather than a predictive factor in early diagnosis. For early-stage breast cancer, nodal involvement is more relevant for prognosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: Which among the following is used in premenopausal women with receptor-positive breast tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Women with hormone receptor-positive (ER+ or PR+) breast tumours can be treated with:

  • Tamoxifen in premenopausal women. It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator with antagonistic activity at the breast and agonistic activity at the uterus and bone.
  • Aromatase inhibitors(AIs)like anastrozole, letrozole and exemestane in postmenopausal women. AIs inhibit aromatase enzymes, which convert androstenedione into estrone. ( Option A, B, D ruled out )

questions.text: Which among the following is not commonly used in a chemotherapy regimen for breast carcinoma patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vincristine is not used in chemotherapy for breast cancer.

  • The most commonly used chemotherapy regimen is the ACT regimen[Adriamycin, Cyclophosphamide, Taxane (Paclitaxel)].
  • Less commonly used regimen includes cyclophosphamide, methotrexate and 5-fluorouracil. (Option A, B, C ruled out )

questions.text: Which among the following agents is used in the HER-2-neu-positive breast carcinoma patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Herceptin (Trastuzumab) is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets the HER-2/neu receptor, which is overexpressed in some breast cancers. It inhibits tumour growth and improves survival in HER-2-positive breast cancer patients. Often used alone or in combination with chemotherapy for early-stage, locally advanced, or metastatic HER-2-positive breast cancer.

Explanation for Other Options:

Methotrexate (option A): Methotrexate is an antimetabolite chemotherapeutic used in various cancers. It is not specific for HER-2-positive breast cancer and does not target the HER-2 receptor.

Tamoxifen (option B): Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used in ER/PR-positive breast cancer. It does not affect the HER-2 receptor, so it is not the primary treatment for HER-2-positive tumours unless there is co-expression of hormone receptors.

Doxorubicin (option D): Doxorubicin is an anthracycline chemotherapy agent used in many types of breast cancer. While it can be part of chemotherapy regimens for HER-2-positive breast cancer, it does not specifically target HER-2, unlike Herceptin.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a complication of lymphatic obstruction in a patient with breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Skin dimpling occurs because of traction on Cooper's ligaments by the tumour. Seen best when the arm is abducted overhead.

Explanation of other options:

Peau d'orange (Option A): Caused by cutaneous lymphatic oedema due to dermal infiltration by malignant cells.

Lymphoedema (Option C): Neoplastic infiltration of the axilla can cause arm swelling as a result of both lymphatic and venous blockage. It can also occur following radical axillary dissection for tumour removal.

Cancer-en-cuirasse (Option D): The skin of the chest is infiltrated with carcinoma and has been likened to a coat. It may be associated with a grossly swollen arm.

questions.text: Which among the following flaps is not used in breast reconstruction surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pectoralis major flap is not used in breast reconstruction surgery.

Autologous tissue reconstruction in breast surgery is done using the following muscle flaps-

  • Latissimus dorsi flap- based on the thoracodorsal pedicle
  • Muscle-preserving perforator abdominal flaps- Ex: Deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap
  • Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap- based on superior or inferior epigastric artery or both.

questions.text: Which among the following is not commonly associated with male breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The BRCA1 mutation is not commonly associated with male breast cancer.

Risk factors for carcinoma of the male breast include:

  • Gynaecomastia (Option A ruled out )
  • Excess endogenous or exogenous oestrogen (Option C ruled out )
  • BRCA2 mutation
  • Klinefelter syndrome(Option D ruled out )

Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer in men.

Diagnosis, grading, treatment and prognosis are the same as female breast cancer.

The BRCA2 mutation mostly causes a hormone receptor-positive tumour. Hence, tamoxifen can be used for treatment.
